author: .vbuterin
content: > I realised yesterday that perhaps the reason Vitalik and some others concluded that "Oil won't work with meta-tx" is because they keep thinking about the worst cases

author: .vbuterin
content: I would say my argument is a bit different

author: .vbuterin
content: It's the whole "oil" thing that's only relevant if we keep thinking about the worst cases

author: .vbuterin
content: Rather, we should openly say "we're going to keep fiddling around with gas costs and you should not use hardcoded gas values anywhere, and if you do then the repricing fork may break your contract and too bad"

author: .vbuterin
content: meta-transactions already can take in gas values for the sub-call from the outside so nothing to worry about there

author: Deleted User
content: I see, yes, that is a worst case of a different kind, the contracts that are relying on the gas costs

author: Deleted User
content: if there is a quantitative way of finding out how much of a worst case it is, or "how common the reliance on the gas costs is", this could be a good direction to go

author: .vbuterin
content:
I'm expecting "not common at all" for two reasons:

1. Application developers have had years of warning that gas costs are going to go up, including eg.  Aragon breaking
2. We can't seem to come up with legitimate reasons to use finite call gas limits other than meta-transactions

author: Deleted User
content: ok, thank you, it gave me some ideas to think about
